subject: RE: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: ... class Xxx extends Assert implements Test ? Never tried it though... ... That is the case already: public class Assert... static public void
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Berin Loritsch [mailto:bloritsch@...]
> ...
>
> Another issue I have is that while JUnit defines the Test interface,
> it only really expects the TestCase base class. It is unclear how
> the Test interface interacts with the system. Sometimes I would much
> rather work with my own base class that is completely separate from
> JUnit. The Assert class should be made a static utility clasee, not
> a base class as well. That would allow us to work with the assert
> methods from any class something like this is much better:
>

class Xxx extends Assert implements Test ?
Never tried it though...

> Assert.isTrue( myObject.rocks() );
>
> than this:
>
> assertTrue( myObject.rocks() );
>
> ...
>
> What I would like to see is the following:
>
> * Explicit use of interfaces--make the contracts clear, and code the
> test runners/collectors to use the interfaces and not the base
> classes. If there are different contracts with a type of
> test/suite,
> then it needs a new interface.
>
> * Making Assert into a set of static utilities so that we don't have
> to inherit it to make it useful.
>

That is the case already:

public class Assert...
static public void assertTrue(boolean condition){
assertTrue(null, condition);
}
static public void fail(String message)...

The downside is of course not being able to override those methods...
(redefining assertTrue(String, boolean) will not change behavior of
assertTrue(boolean) as with instance methods)

> ...
> * Explicit declaration of the TestCase being the Leaf of the
> model, not
> a branch (as it is now treated). A different interface
> for TestSuite
> and TestCase will help.
>

When writing tests, it is very usefull to group related tests together in a
single java file .
It may be clearer on the "internals" side if there would be a
TestMethodInvoker class that takes a TestCase and a Method and invokes the
method on the instance.
You could get rid of the TestCase(String nameThatIsReallyAMethodName)
constructor. The constructor is most definitely confusing to novice users.
And they are encouraged to put setUp code in the constructor. It is there
anyway, not so the setUp method.
The TestSuite and TestMethodInvoker would participate in the composite
pattern, the TestCase could then just be collection of test methods (and no
longer implement Test, behavior extracted to TestMethodInvoker ).
Is that a good idea ?
Downside is backward compatibility, of course...
